entry.title: IFRS 18 Explained: What SAP S/4HANA Customers Need to Know Before 2027
entry.content:
Spoiler
 

IFRS 18 introduces one of the biggest changes to financial statement presentation in decades, replacing IAS 1 and redefining how companies structure their Profit and Loss statements. This blog breaks down the new categories, required subtotals, MPM rules, and cash-flow changes in simple, human language ‚Äî and explains how SAP is preparing to support customers across S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, and On-Premise. With comparative reporting for 2026 and mandatory adoption from 2027, now is the time for finance and IT teams to understand what‚Äôs coming and how to prepare their SAP landscape.

What Is IFRS 18 and Why Is It Important?

IFRS 18 is a brand-new reporting standard released by the IASB. It replaces IAS 1 (Presentation of Financial Statements) and becomes effective on January 1, 2027.

In simple terms, IFRS 18 changes how companies present their Income Statement (P&L) and how they explain their financial performance.

Think of it as a cleaner, more structured way to show:

  • Where money comes from
  • Where it goes
  • What part of the business truly drives performance

The goal is to:

  • Make financial statements easier to understand
  • Improve consistency across companies
  • Increase transparency for investors
  • Make comparison between companies more fair and simple

What‚Äôs Changing in the Profit and Loss Statement? 

IFRS 18 completely reorganizes the Profit and Loss (P&L) structure.
Instead of mixing items together, companies must now classify every income and expense into new categories:

New Mandatory Categories

  • Operating: Day-to-day business activities
  • Investing: Returns or costs related to long-term investments
  • Financing: Borrowings, interest, and funding-related items
  • Income Tax: All tax-related items
  • Discontinued Operations: Business operations that are shut down or sold

New Required Subtotals

Companies must show these subtotals:

  • Operating Profit
  • Profit or Loss Before Financing and Income Tax
  • Profit or Loss

This improves clarity and avoids situations where different companies calculate ‚Äúoperating profit‚Äù differently.

What Are Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs)?

IFRS 18 introduces strict rules for something many companies already do:
show custom KPIs like ‚ÄúAdjusted EBITDA,‚Äù ‚ÄúCore Profit,‚Äù or ‚ÄúUnderlying Margin.‚Äù

These are called Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs).

Under IFRS 18, companies MUST:

  • Explain how the measure is calculated
  • Explain why it is useful
  • Provide a reconciliation to an official IFRS subtotal
  • Include this reconciliation in the notes, and it must be audited

This improves trust and transparency around custom metrics that companies use to tell their story.

Changes to the Cash Flow Statement

IFRS 18 also updates IAS 7 (Cash Flow Statements).
Previously, companies had flexibility in classifying certain cash flows.

Under IFRS 18:

  • Dividends paid ‚Üí must be shown under Investing activities
  • Interest paid ‚Üí must be shown under Financing activities
  • Interest received ‚Üí must be shown under Investing activities

This eliminates the old ‚Äúchoice-based‚Äù method and brings global consistency.

Impact on Financial Reporting and Disclosure

IFRS 18 affects several areas of financial reporting:

P&L Structure

Companies must reorganize their charts of accounts and reporting hierarchies.

Disclosures and Notes

More detail is required, especially around MPMs, aggregation rules, and reconciliation.

Comparative Reporting

Mandatory disclosure of 2026 figures in the new IFRS 18 structure when reporting for 2027.

What Does This Mean for Companies Using SAP?

SAP is currently analysing the full impact of IFRS 18 and consulting with customers through Customer Engagement Initiatives.

Key areas SAP is reviewing include:

  • Functional areas
  • General Ledger structure
  • Valuation processes
  • Reporting frameworks in S/4HANA
  • Group Reporting layouts
  • Cash-flow classifications
  • Universal Journal (ACDOCA) extensibility

SAP expects to release a formal solution approach by December 2025(as documented in SAP Note-https://me.sap.com/notes/3670330/E) . This guidance is expected to be included in the IFRS 18 updates for SAP Group Reporting as part of the 1SG content package.

The solution may differ across editions:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    ‚Üí Expect more standardized, pre-delivered content
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
    ‚Üí More flexibility with governance
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
    ‚Üí Potentially greater configurability

SAP will deliver updates through notes, documentation, and future releases.

How Customers Can Prepare Today

Even before SAP finalizes its solution, companies can begin preparing by:

‚úî Reviewing current P&L structures
‚úî Identifying where income/expense items will map under IFRS 18
‚úî Understanding new disclosure requirements
‚úî Reviewing cash-flow classifications
‚úî Collecting internal MPM definitions
‚úî Engaging with SAP through CEI or Customer Influence Requests

Early preparation will make the transition smoother when IFRS 18 becomes mandatory.

Conclusion

IFRS 18 represents a major shift in how companies communicate their financial performance. The new structure, required subtotals, stricter rules for custom KPIs, and updates to cash flow presentation will significantly impact both finance teams and system configurations.

As outlined in SAP Note 3670330, SAP is developing a comprehensive solution targeted for late 2025, with further updates expected as IFRS 18 continues to evolve. In my view, this is the right time for organizations to start understanding the new requirements, assess their current data and reporting structures, and begin preparing their SAP landscapes for a smooth transition.

More updates will come as SAP refines its roadmap ‚Äî stay tuned.

entry.title: Direct Debit Advance Notices for Mandates in Contract Accounting (S/4HANA & S/4HANA Cloud Private)
entry.content:
This blog post introduces the procedure of creating an advance notice to inform payers about future direct debit payment collection in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. It is aim for the usage related to direct debit mandates in Contract Accounting.

If you want to know more about direct debit mandates, see the SAP Help Portal documentation Management of Direct Debit Mandate | SAP Help Portal.

If you want to know more about this topic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud public edition, see the blog post Direct Debit Advance Notices for Mandates in Contract Accounting.

What is Advance Notices?

Before the collection of the future direct debit payments, the payee can send an advance notice to inform the payer about the payment collection.

Prerequisites

Before creating direct debit advance notices, you must complete the following customizing activities:

  1. Setting up the number ranges for advance notices
  2. Activating the advance notice function
  3. Configuring the output of advance notices, including form templates, email templates and form template for correspondence

Setting up the number ranges for advance notices

This activity allows you to set up a range of numbers within which the advance notices are valid.

  1. Open the Enter Number Ranges for Direct Debit Prenotifications using the transaction FPN11.
  2. Create entries of numerical ranges between which the direct debit advance notices are valid.

Activating the Advance Notice Function

In this activity you activate the direct debit advance notice function. Complete the following activations in different steps:

  • Open the Define General Settings activity using  the transaction DDMA_CENTRALSET_FICA.
    Select the checkbox.
  • Open the Define Payment Methods using the transaction FQP1.
    In this activity you activate the direct debit advance notice for the payment method by countries/regions.
    In the Payment Methods under Required master record specification group box, select the Direct Debit Prenotification checkbox.
  • Open Company Code Details for Payment using the transaction FQP4.
    In this activity you activate the direct debit advance notice for the specific company code.
    Select your company code and double click.
    In the Specifications for SEPA Payments/Direct Debit Mandate group box, select the Direct Debit Pre-notification checkbox.

    In this activity you activate the direct debit advance notice for the payment method by countries/regions.
    In the Payment Methods under Required master record specification group box, select the Direct Debit Prenotification checkbox.

Correspondence

The standard correspondence type ‚Äú0048‚Äù is used to generate output and SAP provides pre-defined application form FIN_CA_DDM_ADVANCE_NOTICE for generating the output.

You can re-define the output in the Print Workbench: Application Form transaction (EFRM) to prepare your own application form.

If you redefine your application form, open the Define Application Forms for Correspondence activity (view V_TFK070F in the transaction SM30) to replace the SAP default application form.

You can also implement BAdI FKKCORR_EVENTS_CREATE based on your business requirements.

Procedure of Creating Direct Debit Advance Notices in Contract Accounting

If you activate advance notice for a payment method, you cannot generate payment through the Payment Run transaction (FPY1) for this payment method unless the advance notice for this payment has been created. To create an advance notice for the payment, see the following steps.

  1. Create an advance notice using the transaction FPYP.
    Fill the values in the necessary fields.

    When you schedule a run, you can see the message about direct debit pre-notification with its number is created in the job list.

  2. You can display, change, reverse, or delete the advance notices of mandates using the following transactions:
    1. Display: FPPRN3
    2. Change: FPPRN2
    3. Reverse: FPPRN8
  3. Print the correspondence using the transaction FPCOPARA.
    Fill in the fields in the Run ID and schedule program run. You can refresh the Run Status until you see the Program Run is set to Complete.
    To check the output, you can use Correspondence History transaction (CORRHIST)
    When the Advance notice is generated, you can continue and use transaction FPY1 to generate Payment.
  4. Execute a payment run with advance notices using the transaction FPY1.
    You must select the Pre-Notified Items checkbox to include the open items in payments.

    After you schedule a run, you should see a message - Payment is made in accordance with direct debit pre-notification (num.)

You can ensure that the direct debit is executed only within or after a given number of days after the direct debit advance notices.

Implement your own logic in the event 657 to set Execution Date. Then you can use the option Execution Date To on the selection screen in the Payment Run transaction (FPY1).

DATA: lv_pnexd      TYPE pnexd_kk,
      lv_ddan_calid TYPE tfacd-ident,
      lv_num_days   TYPE i.

  " Only for Advance Notice for Direct Debit Mandate
  IF i_fkkprnh-mndid IS INITIAL OR
     i_fkkprnh-anwnd NE cl_fkkid_ddm_ut=>get_anwnd_for_ddm_fica( ).
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  " Calculate Minimum Number of Days between Notification and Collection
  IF i_process = 'I'.

    lv_num_days    = 10. " set default value for number of days
    lv_ddan_calid  = ''. " set default calendar id

    CALL FUNCTION 'FKK_ADD_WORKINGDAY'
      EXPORTING
        i_date      = sy-datum
        i_days      = lv_num_days
        i_calendar1 = lv_ddan_calid
      IMPORTING
        e_date      = lv_pnexd.
    IF c_fkkprnh_cus-pnexd < lv_pnexd.
      c_fkkprnh_cus-pnexd = lv_pnexd.
    ENDIF.
  ELSEIF i_process = 'U'.
*   nothing to change
  ELSEIF i_process = 'R'.
*   nothing to change
  ENDIF.

 

If the standard selection criteria in the Payment Run transaction (FPY1) are not enough, you can add more rules in the event 610. With this event, you can reject a payment for processing when the Execution Date does not meet the requirements regarding of the number of days between the notification and the payment collection date.

*‚ÄØimplementation‚ÄØ-‚ÄØDirect‚ÄØDebit‚ÄØMandates‚ÄØ-‚ÄØAdvance‚ÄØNotice
